Context:
The Honours Bachelor of Commerce (Culinary Management) is an undergraduate degree program offered by George Brown College that combines culinary, food studies, commerce, and externship experiences. Students will gain knowledge and skills in eight key areas: culinary proficiency, culinary theory, accounting and finance, marketing and communications, human resources and risk management, specialized business, research, and general knowledge (liberal studies).

The program includes a unique and robust externship experience where students can work with employers and industry partners to identify potential work experience opportunities. Students are encouraged to pursue self-directed industry work experience. This valuable work experience can be added to their resume.

After graduation, career options include food service employment areas such as director of operations in multi-unit food service, corporate/menu development chef, director of food service in retirement facilities and chains, executive chef, director of food & beverage in hospitality and tourism, corporate or regional chef, district manager, regional manager, and regional vice-president in contract food service management, and development chef or sales in food processors and brokers.

Context:
The text provides information about a culinary management program offered by George Brown College. The program aims to help students develop strategies to achieve organizational objectives in various food service environments, manage partnerships and customer relationships, and plan and execute contemporary cooking techniques, among other skills. The tuition fees for the first two semesters of the program are listed as $9,805 for domestic students and $23,685 for international students. However, these fees do not include the cost of co-op work terms, which is approximately $500 each. Additional costs for small wares and books are estimated to be between $100-$300 and $500-$1,000 per year, respectively. The program includes the cost of a culinary kit, safety shoes, and Chef School uniform in semester 1 tuition fees.

Program: Culinary Management
Institution: George Brown College
Objective: Develop strategies to achieve organizational objectives in various food service environments, manage partnerships and customer relationships, plan and execute contemporary cooking techniques, among other skills.
Domestic Tuition (first two semesters): $9,805
International Tuition (first two semesters): $23,685
Co-op work terms: Approximately $500 each
Additional costs:
- Small wares: $100-$300
- Books: $500-$1,000 per year
Included in semester 1 tuition fees: Culinary kit, safety shoes, and Chef School uniform.

Context:
The George Brown Culinary Kit contains items not detailed in the provided text.

The program offered by George Brown College is an applied degree, and it has been granted a consent by the Ministry of Colleges and Universities to offer this program for a seven-year term starting October 11, 2016. The applicants must meet certain admission requirements:

1. For students with an Ontario Secondary School Diploma (OSSD): six grade 12 university (U) or university/college (M) courses are required, which include grade 12 (U) English and any grade 12 (U) mathematics. The applicant should have a grade of 60 per cent or higher in English and math and an overall average of 65 per cent in six grade 12 (U) or (M) courses, with recommended courses being basic computer software applications.

2. For mature students (19 years of age or older without OSSD): they need to have grade 12 (U) English and grade 12 (U) mathematics, a grade of 65 per cent or higher in English and math, and post-secondary courses in English and mathematics will be considered. There is no mature student testing for the required credits, but applicants should meet the English and math credit requirements.

English language proficiency is mandatory for success in the program, and applicants must meet one of the following English language proficiency tests: George Brown College ESL Level 9, TOEFL 84 overall and 21 in each skill band (online), IELTS 6.5 overall and 6.0 in each skill band, or MELAB 85; CAEL overall 70 (writing 60).

No specific financial assistance or international fees details are mentioned in the text.

Students admitted during this period are guaranteed the opportunity to complete the program within a reasonable time frame. The text mentions two types of students: domestic and international. International students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System and can find specific admission requirements on the International Admissions page. Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges. For inquiries about financial aid, including OSAP, scholarships, and bursaries, students can contact the Financial Aid Office or visit the Financial Aid web page. The college has a Honours Bachelor of Commerce (H315) program. Students can contact the Contact Centre at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-875-5559) or 1-800-265-2002 for more information about George Brown College. International students can contact one of the college's international recruitment representatives by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry, and they can visit the International Contact Us page for more information. The text mentions several programs related to culinary management: Culinary Management (H100), Honours Bachelor of Commerce (Culinary Management) (Bridging) (H316). Students interested in visiting the campus can register for an Open House Discovery Day. Allergens like nuts, dairy, and shellfish are used in practical labs, and the college is sensitive to religious observances but may not meet specific dietary laws related to halal and kosher foods.

Context: The text describes two programs offered at George Brown College: Honours Bachelor of Commerce (Culinary Management) (H316) and Honours Bachelor of Food Studies (H317). The Culinary Management program is a four-year degree that provides a balance between management and culinary skills, preparing students for leadership roles in the hospitality industry. Students learn various aspects of the hospitality industry beyond just restaurant management, giving them flexibility in their career paths. The academic standard of this program is high, with knowledgeable professors and small class sizes that facilitate personal connections. Real-life case studies, guest speakers, and hands-on projects keep students connected to the industry throughout their education. Externships in the first and third years provide valuable real-world experience. Upon graduation, students feel well-prepared and confident with the skills and knowledge gained from the program. Yasemin Gencay is a graduate of this program with an Honours Bachelor's Degree. Potential applicants can visit the campus for a tour or information session, sign up to receive tailored resources, and learn more about available programs and life at George Brown College.
